quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: North Dakota and Alaska
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, people, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In 1953, television first came to Alaska. What were the call letters of the first broadcasting television station in Alaska?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: KENI

questions.question: This U.S. Senator from the 60s and 70s was known as Senator Wheat for his work at getting a higher price for wheat which during that time North Dakota was the leading producer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Milton R. Young

questions.question: What was the Darfur region of western Sudan named after?

options.text: A British explorer named William Darfur
A tribe of people called the Fur tribe
The Fur river running through the region
The arabic word darfur meaning stove or furnace

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A tribe of people called the Fur tribe

questions.question: General George Armstrong Custer left Fort Lincoln on the southern edge of this North Dakota town (named after the Native American tribes from that area) on his fateful trip to The Little Bighorn.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mandan

questions.question: The North Dakota State Fair is held in which city each August?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Minot

questions.question: The Darfur crisis in western Sudan began as a result of tribal warfare between two black African tribes, the Fur tribe and the Zaghawa tribe.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Cleveland Indians 1st baseman/DH, Travis Hafner was born and raised in this North Dakota town.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sykeston

questions.question: The Alaska state flag was designed by a 13-year-old.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which US President signed the Treaty of Purchase between the United States and Russia, which brought about the formal transfer of Alaska from Russia to the US?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Andrew Johnson

questions.question: The best walleye fishing lake in North America, according to Field and Stream Magazine, is this lake in northeast central North Dakota.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Devils Lake

questions.question: Which U.S. president stated he would have never been president had it not been for his experiences in North Dakota as a cattle rancher?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodore Roosevelt

questions.question: There is much speculation as to how many people died as a direct result of the Darfur conflict. What figure do most Non-governmental organizations use when calculating the total number of deaths?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 400,000

questions.question: Which United Nations representative was forced to leave Sudan in October, 2006 because of comments made about the Sudanese Army?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jan Pronk

questions.question: This city and historical park in North Dakota boasts the rarity of having an albino buffalo. At the birth of White Cloud, Native American people from around the country came to view this creature, which is looked on spiritually by Native American Indians.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jamestown

questions.question: This Police Woman was born and raised at Kulm, ND which also was the flax capital of North America!
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Angie Dickinson

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Darfur and Store
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, alternative, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What does Maundy Thursday, also known as Holy Thursday, commemorate?

options.text: The Last Supper of Jesus Christ with the Apostles

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Last Supper of Jesus Christ with the Apostles

questions.question: What nocturnal omnivorous animal is an Australian alternative to the Easter Bunny?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bilby

questions.question: If there is a crowd of children in a Darfur camp screaming Kawaja, kawaja! what is there in the center of the crowd?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A white person

questions.question: What is the name of the volcanic mountainous region in the center of Darfur, Sudan?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jebel Mara

questions.question: What jewellery company is famous for designing exquisite jewel-encrusted eggs for the Russian Imperial Court?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fabergé

questions.question: The two buildings of Marina City, one of the first complexes referred to as the city within a city, are often compared to this food item.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Corn

questions.question: Name the Roman governor of Judaea who, according to the gospels, authorized the Crucifixion of Jesus.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pontius Pilate

questions.question: Designed by Skidmore, Owings  Merrill LLP, this building consists of 9 bundled square tubes, each 75 feet wide with no columns between the core and the perimeter.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sears Tower

questions.question: This building, designed by Louis H. Sullivan, is one of the most famous early skyscrapers housing a flagship department store. This store appears in Theodore Dreisers novel Sister Carrie. It was named a National Historic Landmark in 1975. Name the store.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Carson Pirie Scott

questions.question: What Easter television special, released in 1971, was based on the novel The Easter Bunny That Overslept?

options.text: Its the Easter Beagle, Charlie Brown
Here Comes the Mad March Hare

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Here Comes Peter Cottontail

questions.question: According to a tradition among followers of Eastern Christianity, this disciple of Jesus Christ brought cooked eggs at his tomb and they miraculously turned red.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mary Magdalene

questions.question: When the fighting in Darfur began in 2003, the locals moved into IDP (Internationally Displaced Persons) camps to avoid the fighting and seek aid. According to the registration taken, about how many people received aid in Darfur’s largest camp in from 2003 to 2005?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 150,000

questions.question: In May 2006 the Joint Equality Movement (JEM), one of the main rebel groups in Darfur, signed a peace deal with the Government of Sudan. As a result the rebel group split in two causing the pro-government side and the pro-rebel side to fight against each other.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Most of the black Africans in the Darfur region are Christian, which is another reason why there is conflict between their tribes and the nomadic Arabs.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What is another name for Golgotha, the site where Jesus was crucified?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Calvary

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Palace and Feast
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, sanssouci, atatürk. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The Potala Palace was a chief residence of the Dalai Lama until the 14th Dalai Lama fled to India.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Sanssouci, the former summer palace of Frederick the Great, was built in this style.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rococo

questions.question: What feast commemorating Jesus triumphal entry into Jerusalem marks the beginning of the Holy Week?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Palm Sunday

questions.question: What feast celebrated 50 days after Easter Sunday commemorates the descent of the Holy Spirit upon Christs disciples?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pentecost

questions.question: What day and year did the famous Battle of Culloden near Culloden, Scotland occur?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: April 16, 1746

questions.question: Who directed the 2004 movie The Passion of the Christ, which covers the final twelve hours of Jesus life?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mel Gibson

questions.question: Gamzigrad is an ancient Roman complex of palaces located in this European country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Serbia

questions.question: The space between windows in the facade of the Stroganov Palace in Saint Petersburg, Russia features a mans profile.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, the first president of the Republic of Turkey, used this palace as a presidential residence.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dolmabahçe Palace

questions.question: The name of this Palace means “Forty Columns” in Persian.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chehel Sotoun

questions.question: The Winter Palace, the official residence of Russian Tsars, is located in this Russian city.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saint Petersburg

questions.question: The Culloden Moor, Scotland, the site of the Battle of Culloden, was once known by another name, Drummoisse Moor.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The name of this Iranian grand palace means high gate.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ali Qapu

questions.question: The Imperial harem of Topkapi Palace in Istanbul contained more than 400 rooms.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What palace is known as the official residence of the President of Brazil?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Palacio da Alvorada

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Scotland and Alaska
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, claimant, bering. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: When individuals file for bankruptcy in the USA they file under this section of the Uniform Commercial Code.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chapter 13

questions.question: On November 7th, 2006, Sarah Palin, became the first female governor of the State of Alaska.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The name of the exiled Scottish Jacobite claimant to the thrones of England, Scotland, and Ireland was James Francis Edward Stuart.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Czar Alexander II of Russia agreed to sell Alaska to the U.S. for two cents an acre.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which is the patron saint of Scotland?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Andrew

questions.question: Who smuggled the Scottish Bonnie Prince Charlie out of Scotland?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Flora MacDonald

questions.question: What musher and his dog relayed diphtheria vaccine via the Iditarod Trail to fight an epidemic in Nome in 1925 and became national heroes?

options.text: John Muir and Rin Tin Tin

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leonhard Seppala and Balto

questions.question: Who was vice president of the US  when Congress gave final approval to begin construction of the Alaska pipeline?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spiro Agnew

questions.question: What is the common name for Prudhoe Bay?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The North Slope

questions.question: The term used to describe the head of family/village in Scotland is laird.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Vitus Bering and naturalist George Stellar were the first white people to set foot in Alaska in 1735 .
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Construction of the Alaska Railroad began in 1914.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: The Trans-Alaska pipeline provided what percent of domestic oil for the US when completed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 25%

questions.question: What happened in 1964 in south-central Alaska?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: tsunamis and earthquake

questions.question: President Warren Harding  drove the final spike in the Alaska Railroad.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Bankruptcy and Loss
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, user, athletes. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What is the real first name of Screech Diamond of Saved by the Bell fame, who was forced to declare bankruptcy due to the loss of hundreds of thousands of dollars?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dustin

questions.question: All of these great athletes declared bankruptcy: Billy Sims, Leon Spinks, Lawrence Taylor, Johnny Unitas, Sheryl Swoopes.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: She was an actress famous for her role in Moulin Rouge. She is even more famous for her marriages, her sisters, and for being arrested for battery. Who is this actress who was forced into bankruptcy in 1994?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Zsa Zsa Gabor

questions.question: In the United States, elections are held on the Tuesday after the 1st Monday in November.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: McDonalds is the worlds largest user of toys.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Día de los Muertos, or Day of the Dead, is celebrated in what country on November 1st and 2nd?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mexico

questions.question: This man (along with his half-brother) tried to corner the worlds silver market. His failure led to his bankruptcy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nelson Bunker Hunt

questions.question: Wheaties is the Breakfast of Champions. At 18 appearances, which of these sports figures has graced the cover of the Wheaties box more than any other sports figure?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Michael Jordan

questions.question: What famous television host deemed Americas Oldest Teenager celebrates his birthday in November?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dick Clark

questions.question: This blond beauty, born in  Athens, Georgia in 1953, made millions as a movie star but went bankrupt  due, in part, to her purchase of the entire town of Baselton, Georgia.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kim Bassinger

questions.question: She was a very popular singer with many corporate sponserships. Her open antagonism to  homosexuals led to the loss of these sponsorships and singing success.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anita Bryant

questions.question: In 1936 this founder of General Motors had a debt of $914,231 forcing bankruptcy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William C. Durant

questions.question: Two Out of Three [one might say ] Aint Bad, but this singer/actor had a $1,600,000 debt in 1983.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: MeatLoaf

questions.question: What major annual thoroughbred horse race is held in Australia during the first week of November?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Melbourne Cup

questions.question: Although he never filed for bankruptcy, this very smart and very great American President left a $107,000 debt for his heirs.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Jefferson

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Massachusetts and July
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, massachusetts, cape. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Coppertone was born in the kitchen of Miami pharmacist, Benjamin Green. It became one of Americas leading sun care products through the strength of its advertising campaign featuring the Coppertone Girl. What actress got her start as the 1965 Coppertone Girl?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jodie Foster

questions.question: Niles Beach is one of Cape Cods popular beaches.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What year was the first Boston Marathon run?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1897

questions.question: Andrew Faneuil, a wealthy merchant, built Faneuil Hall and gave it to Boston on its completion in 1742.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: A series of riots, among the worst in US history, were started on July 23, 1967. Where did this event take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Detroit, Michigan

questions.question: What famous basketball players father was murdered on July 23, 1993?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Michael Jordan

questions.question: Rocky Marciano is from which city in Massachusetts?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Brockton

questions.question: This Filipino-American serial killer went on a murder spree, killing five people, that ended with his suicide on July 23, 1997.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Andrew Cunanan

questions.question: Which eclectic pro marijuana actor was born on July 23, 1961?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Woody Harrelson

questions.question: Nathaniel Hawthorne is said to have changed the spelling of his name for what reason?

options.text: He was a descendant of Nathan Hawthorne, accused of an Indian massacre.
He was a descendant of John Hathorne, a judge in the Salem witch trials.
It was the one he chose to write under.
He was a descendant of Nathaniel Hathorne, a judge in the Salem witch trials.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was a descendant of John Hathorne, a judge in the Salem witch trials.

questions.question: One of Nathaniel Hawthornes stories is called The Old Manse (Mosses from an Old Manse). The Old Manse was Nathaniel and his wife Sofias first home and is located in Concord, Massachusetts.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This famous royal couple were married on July 23, 1986. The marriage ended some years later in a highly publicized divorce.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson

questions.question: On May 5, 1920 two Italian-Americans, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, were arrested, tried, and executed for the April 15, 1920 murders of a South Braintree paymaster and security guard and theft of the payroll.

options.text: He was at the Italian consulate in Boston.
He was visiting friends in West Bridgewater.
He was at work and had a time-card to prove it.
He was in Plymouth peddling fish at the time.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was at the Italian consulate in Boston.

questions.question: Which member of the RB group Destinys Child was born on July 23,1980?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Michelle Williams

questions.question: The ship that can be seen in Plymouth, Massachusetts is called the Mayflower.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False
